review.title: Bayesian Optimal Active Search and Surveying
review.abstract: We consider two active binary-classification problems with atypical objectives. In the first, active search, our goal is to actively uncover as many members of a given class as possible. In the second, active surveying, our goal is to actively query points to ultimately predict the proportion of a given class. Numerous real-world problems can be framed in these terms, and in either case typical model-based concerns such as generalization error are only of secondary importance.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text: We introduced Bayesian Optimal Policy to two atypical problems of active learning related to binary classification, which we call active search and active surveying; the former focuses on actively identifying members of a set of identified targets as soon as possible, and the latter focuses on predicting the proportion of data set that belongs to a particular class; our approach was to define reasonable utility functions for these problems and derive optimal Bayesian policy for each of them; the optimal policy for each of these targets takes the same form, but in practice the behavior of each may vary dramatically due to the sharply contrasting underlying utility functions; in addition to introducing the active surveying problem, we expanded previous work on active search in two ways: First, we demonstrated a theoretical result showing that the potential benefit of more distant horizons is unlimited; and then we presented an industry and limited method of circumscribing exponential search that may be required for certain types of active search; and, the active search policy that may be applied to specific areas.

Examples include generalization error (Zhu et al., 2003) and optimality criteria related to the Fisher information, such as A-optimality (Schein & Ungar, 2007).
The problem as defined there can also be seen as a Bayesian multi-armed bandit, and the optimal policy can also be recovered via a Gittins index (Gittins et al., 2011).

metadata.abstractText: We consider two active binary-classification problems with atypical objectives. In the first, active search, our goal is to actively uncover as many members of a given class as possible. In the second, active surveying, our goal is to actively query points to ultimately predict the proportion of a given class. Numerous real-world problems can be framed in these terms, and in either case typical model-based concerns such as generalization error are only of secondary importance. We approach these problems via Bayesian decision theory; after choosing natural utility functions, we derive the optimal policies. We provide three contributions. In addition to introducing the active surveying problem, we extend previous work on active search in two ways. First, we prove a novel theoretical result, that less-myopic approximations to the optimal policy can outperform more-myopic approximations by any arbitrary degree. We then derive bounds that for certain models allow us to reduce (in practice dramatically) the exponential search space required by a naïve implementation of the optimal policy, enabling further lookahead while still ensuring that optimal decisions are always made.
